com.pump.text

Class TextDiff.DiffSegment

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pump.text.TextDiff.DiffSegment
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Comparable<TextDiff.DiffSegment>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    TextDiff.SharedSegment, TextDiff.SplitSegment
    Enclosing class:
    TextDiff

    public abstract static class TextDiff.DiffSegment
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Comparable<TextDiff.DiffSegment>
    This represents a segment of a diff solution.

    This abstract class has two subclasses: the SharedSegment is a String that is shared between both branch A and B, and the {code SplitSegment} is two Strings that deviate depending on which branch you're following.

    This is illustrated in the TextDiff javadoc with diagrams. Each column in those diagrams is a DiffSegment object.

    This object is a node in a linked list. Originally you are given the head of the list as the complete solution, and you can call next() to traverse to the tail of this list.

    If this is put into a sorted data structure, these segments are sorted by complexity (with the least complex graph sorted first).

      • getText

        public abstract java.lang.String getText(TextDiff.Branch branch,
                                         boolean appendSubsequentNodes)
        Return the text of this node.
        Parameters:
        branch - the branch of this node to consider. For a SharedSegment this argument is ignored, but for a SplitSegment this argument controls which String is returned.
        appendSubsequentNodes - if true then this appends all subsequent nodes. This is useful if just want the whole String of a branch. If you need to study individual pieces more carefully then you may want to pass false here.
        Returns:
        the text of this node. This returns the raw text with no quotations or square/curly brackets.

      • append

        public TextDiff.DiffSegment append(java.lang.String strA,
                                   java.lang.String strB)
        Clone this node and append the two Strings provided to each respective branch.

        Warning: some splits are considered "unnecessary", and are rejected. When an unnecessary split is detected this method returns null. For example the diff "[h]{h}ello" is rejected, because when the first characters of a split are the same: we have a redundant/unnecessary split.

        Parameters:
        strA - the String to append to branch A.
        strB - the String to append to branch B.
        Returns:
        the new node that represents this node + the arguments or null if this split is not allowed.

      • getComplexity

        public int getComplexity()
        Return the complexity of this segment. Lower values are considered simpler and therefore "better" when pruning solutions.
        Returns:
        the complexity of this segment.

      • calculateComplexity

        protected abstract int calculateComplexity()

      • isSubset

        public boolean isSubset(TextDiff.Branch x)
        Return true if branch x is a subset of the opposite branch.

        For example if string A is "underwater" and string B is "water", then the diff of these will be "[under]water". So calling myDiff.isSubset(Branch.B) will return true, because the B branch ("water") is a subset of the A branch ("underwater").

        However if string A is "underwater" and string B is "watered", then the diff will be "[under]water{ed}". Here calling isSubset(..) for either branch returns false, because neither is a subset of the other.

        The examples above are trivial because they cluster all the words together, but the utility of this method has to do with abbreviations. For example given the strings "association" and "assn": the second branch is considered a subset of the first, even though the diff resembles "ass[ociatio]n".

        As a word of caution: this is helpful at identifying abbreviations, but it can also be misleading. For example "ne" is a subset of "northeast" (as expected), but "ne" is also a subset of "northwest". Similarly "intl" is a subset of "international", but it is also a subset of "intelligence". And "cm" is a subset of "centimeter", but it also a subset of "camp".

        Parameters:
        b - the branch that might be a subset of the opposite branch.
        Returns:
        true if the argument branch is a subset of the opposite branch.

      • containsSplit

        public boolean containsSplit(java.util.Collection<java.lang.String> values)
        Return true if this graph contains a split where one of the words is in the argument provided.
        Parameters:
        values - a collection of Strings to check against.
        Returns:
        true if this graph contains a split that contains text from the argument.
